StrangeWoman
sources.description: Title: The Strange Woman Summary: In 1820s New England beautiful but poor and manipulative Jenny Hager marries rich old man Isaiah Poster but also seduces his son and his company foreman. Directed by: Edgar G. Ulmer, Douglas Sirk Actors: Production Company: Hunt Stromberg Productions Release Date: 25 October 1946 (USA) Aspect Ratio: 1.37 : 1 Beautiful Jenny Hager finds she can always get what she wants from the men in the 1820's port of Bangor, Maine. Freed by his death from her drunkard father she soon manoeuvres herself into a position to marry a middle-aged monied local businessman. Though she often uses his money to do good, she continues to consider all other men fair game.

sources.title: Strange Woman Movie
sources.description: Hedy Lamarr and George Sanders in a movie based on Ben Ames Williams' novel of early 19th-century Maine. The IMDB entry is here . The video files with "_1946" in the file-name are of higher quality; the picture is sharper and there are no covered up watermarks. However, they have a very slight problem. At 1:25:26 the sign on the church is in French instead of English. The mpeg2 file is ready to be loaded into DVDAuthorGUI (a free program) to create a DVD to watch on your television.

sources.title: The Strange Woman (1946) | Colorized Public Domain Classic Drama with Hedy Lamarr & George Sanders
sources.description:
The Strange Woman (1946) is an American melodrama directed by Edgar G. Ulmer and adapted from Ben Ames Williamsâ€™ novel of the same name. This colorized and restored edition revives a striking period drama that showcases Hedy Lamarr in one of her strongest and most complex performances. Set in 19th-century Bangor, Maine, the story combines ambition, romance, and moral conflict in a way that reflects both the allure and dangers of unchecked desire. With Ulmerâ€™s atmospheric direction and a cast led by Lamarr, George Sanders, and Louis Hayward, the film stands out as a powerful example of Hollywoodâ€™s post-war fascination with flawed heroines and psychological drama.

Plot Summary:
The story follows Jenny Hager (Hedy Lamarr), a young woman growing up in Bangor, Maine, during the early 1800s. Scarred by an abusive childhood, Jenny learns to use her beauty and intelligence to manipulate the men around her, climbing the social ladder while pursuing wealth and influence. Her outward charm masks ruthless ambition, as she exploits relationships with Ezra Bigbee (Gene Lockhart), his son Ephraim (Louis Hayward), and wealthy businessman Isaiah Poster (George Sanders).

Jenny marries Isaiah for financial security, but her heart strays toward Ephraim, her childhood friend. This tangled web of deceit, betrayal, and suppressed passion drives the narrative to its tragic climax. The film explores timeless themes of power, morality, and the consequences of selfish choices, with Jenny embodying both victimhood and villainy.

Cast and Crew:
â€¢ Director: Edgar G. Ulmer
â€¢ Producer: Jack Chertok
â€¢ Screenplay: Herbert J. Biberman, Hunt Stromberg
â€¢ Based on: The Strange Woman by Ben Ames Williams
â€¢ Cinematography: Lucien N. Andriot
â€¢ Editing: Richard C. Currier
â€¢ Music: Carmen Dragon

Starring:
â€¢ Hedy Lamarr as Jenny Hager
â€¢ George Sanders as Isaiah Poster
â€¢ Louis Hayward as Ephraim Poster
â€¢ Gene Lockhart as Timothy Hager / Ezra Bigbee
â€¢ Hillary Brooke as Meg Saladine
â€¢ Alan Napier as John Evered

Film Significance:
The Strange Woman is one of Hedy Lamarrâ€™s most acclaimed performances, allowing her to break away from her usual glamorous image and embody a morally ambiguous character. The role demonstrated her range as an actress, though her legacy is often overshadowed by her later reputation as an inventor and Hollywood beauty. The film also highlights Edgar G. Ulmerâ€™s talent as a director capable of creating intense atmosphere on modest budgets, following his cult success with Detour (1945).

Thematically, the film connects to the tradition of femme fatale narratives in classic Hollywood but places them in a 19th-century setting. Its focus on power, sexuality, and female agency was daring for its time, and it remains a fascinating piece of mid-century American cinema. Over the years, it has developed cult appreciation for both Lamarrâ€™s performance and Ulmerâ€™s bold handling of melodrama.

Enhanced Public Domain Explanation:
This film is in the public domain, which means it is completely free of copyright restrictions and can be legally shared, viewed, studied, and preserved without limitation. Colorized Public Domain restores and enhances these historic works through careful digital cleaning, visual restoration, and colorization techniques. Our mission is to ensure that timeless classics like The Strange Woman remain available to a worldwide audience. By presenting them in color and modern quality, we make them more engaging and accessible to younger generations who might otherwise overlook black-and-white cinema. This process respects the original film while providing a new layer of appreciation for todayâ€™s viewers.

Why Watch This Colorized Edition:
The original 1946 release was filmed in black and white, emphasizing shadows, textures, and period detail. While historically authentic, many modern audiences often pass over black-and-white films. By offering a colorized edition, we bring to life the rich costumes, sets, and dramatic atmosphere, giving audiences a new appreciation of Hedy Lamarrâ€™s performance and Ulmerâ€™s striking visuals. This edition bridges the gap between cinematic history and modern viewing habits.

sources.title: The Strange Woman (1946)
sources.description: Isaiah, a 19th-century businessman, has his eye on the beautiful and very young Jenny. Finally of age, she accepts his marriage proposal, but their love affair quickly turns sour. Ephraim, Isaiah's college-age son, comes for a visit, immediately striking up a chemistry with Jenny. She promises marriage -- if he murders his father first. But Jenny also swoons for John, the fiancÃ© of her best friend, Meg. Watch on RetroFlix:Â  https://retroflix.org/the-strange-woman-1946/

Freed by his death from her drunkard father she soon manoeuvres herself into a position to marry a middle-aged monied local businessman. Though she often uses his money to do good, she continues to consider all other men fair game.
